==Japanese==

===Etymology 1===
{{ja-kanjitab|yomi=irr|sort=いつ}}
From {{etyl|ojp|ja|sort=いつ}}.

The presence of other {{etyl|ojp|ja|sort=いつ}} indefinites beginning with {{lang|ja|い}} (''i'') suggests a possible shared root of {{lang|ja|い}} (''i'', possibly “what” or “which”).

Likely cognate with eastern {{etyl|ojp|ja|sort=いつ}} word ''izu'', ''idzu'' (“where”), still used in modern Japanese as part of the word {{m|ja|いずれ|tr=izure||which}}.

====Pronunciation====
* {{l|ja|sc=Latn|訓読み|Kun'yomi}}
* {{IPA|lang=ja|[it͡sɯᵝ]}}

====Pronoun====
{{ja-pos|pronoun|いつ}}

# [[when]], [[which]] [[day]]

=====Usage notes=====
''Itsu'' is most often spelled in hiragana as {{l|ja|いつ}}. ''Itsu'' is more commonly used to mean {{m|en|when}} in terms of dates or days, while ''nanji'' is more commonly used to mean {{m|en|when}} in terms of time of day.

=====Derived terms=====
* {{ja-r|何時も|いつ も}}: [[always]], [[forever]], [[all the time]]

===Etymology 2===
{{ja-kanjitab|なん|じ|yomi=y}}
Compound of {{compound|lang=ja|sort=なんじ|何|tr1=nan|t1=what|時|tr2=ji|t2=hour}}. The ''nan'' portion is from {{etyl|ojp|ja|sort=なんじ}}, the ''ji'' portion is a borrowing from {{etyl|ltc|ja|sort=なんじ}}.

====Pronunciation====
* {{l|ja|sc=Latn|湯桶読み|Yutōyomi}}
* {{IPA|lang=ja|[nã̠ɴd͡ʑi]}}

====Pronoun====
{{ja-pos|pronoun|なんじ}}

# [[what]] [[time]], [[when]]

=====Usage notes=====
''Nanji'' is often spelled in kanji. ''Nanji'' is more commonly used to mean {{m|en|when}} in terms of time of day, while ''itsu'' is more commonly used to mean {{m|en|when}} in terms of dates or days.

===Etymology 3===
{{ja-kanjitab|なん|とき|k2=どき|yomi=k}}
Compound of {{etyl|ojp|ja|sort=なんどき}} elements {{compound|lang=ja|sort=なんどき|何|tr1=nan|t1=what|時|tr2=toki|t2=time}}. The ''toki'' changes to ''doki'' due to {{rendaku|なんどき}}.

====Pronunciation====
* {{l|ja|sc=Latn|訓読み|Kun'yomi}}
* {{IPA|lang=ja|[nã̠ɴdo̞ki]}}

====Alternative forms====
* {{l|ja|何刻}}

====Pronoun====
{{ja-pos|pronoun|なんどき}}

# [[what]] [[time]], [[when]]

=====Usage notes=====
Use is more limited than ''nanji'' or ''itsu''. Most commonly found in set phrase {{lang|ja|いつなんどき}} (''itsu nandoki''), comparable to English phrase “when and at what time”, but only used when expressing ignorance, never used in questions.
